{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3287073,"name":"Niran Schneller","username":"NiranSchneller","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/niranschneller/{size}/212122_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-17T19:26:11.767Z","cooked":"

Hello!

Me and my team have upgraded to the relevant 2024 versions, and have encountered a problem while trying to deploy code.

When first turning on the bot, we can deploy code and drive it around. When trying to redeploy code, it says that the build has failed due to discoverroborio failing (something with TargetDiscoveryWorker).

Communications on the driver station are green.

Additionally, pinging 10.33.39.2 and roboRIO-3339-frc.local gives a normal response.

Does anybody know the root cause of the problem? We have tried reformatting the RIO, reconfguring the router , using different laptops and using an older version of DS.

A fix that works is rebooting the RIO, but then after another redeployment it displays the same error (discoverroborio failed).

We are connected wirelessly.

Thanks in advance,
Niran Schneller.

Probably not it, but is the team number correct in wpilib_preferences.json?

Whats the network connection look like?

  • wired ethernet: laptop direct to rio
  • wired ethernet: laptop to radio port 2, port 1 to rio
  • wired ethernet: laptop to network switch, switch to rio
  • wireless: same as at events
  • USB: A to B “printer” cable laptop to rio

Also, can you share the output of ipconfig /all?

We tried in any way possible.
It looks like the DHCP works, when running ipconfig, we get an IP, and even can ping / ssh to the RIO, though something in the code deployment is messed up.

We had a similar issue on a student’s laptop who was using an out of date version of VScode. Double check you’ve got everything updated on the software side.

will check

We had the same issue earlier this year with the beta, try sshing in manually and see if that works

I was asking for my own understanding, so that answer unfortunately doesn’t help. Are you getting the right IP in each of those circumstances (not saying you need to test them all, but USB generally “just works”, so I’d definitely test that).

Assuming it’s the right IP, are you able to ping the rio (both by mdns name as well as by IP)? If so, check firewall status then attempt to SSH manually.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-01-18T17:08:37.533Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":27.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":450691,"topic_slug":"cant-discover-roborio-while-deploying-code","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":40752,"username":"OfekHarel","name":"Ofek Harel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ofekharel/{size}/134749_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/cant-discover-roborio-while-deploying-code/450691/11","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3287996,"name":"Ofek Harel","username":"OfekHarel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ofekharel/{size}/134749_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-18T17:37:28.845Z","cooked":"

In all configuration we get the correct IP (correct subnet…) And both ping by IP and by mDNS works.
SSHing manually works as well…

We even tried to make a FS compare on the pre and post state of the first deployment (as it works in first deployment only), and nothing out of the ordinary…

We gonna try with a clean formatted laptop that it’s first WPI version will be the latest…

We had a similar issue on a rio 2.0. We had burned the image to the sd card, but forgot to use the imaging tool to set the team number… We could deploy via usb, but not ethernet tether

Hello all,
the problem ended up being assigning an invalid PWM Port in the software, which caused the RIO to crash.

It didn’t output any invalid port issues, because no port sanity check is done on ports < 0 on WPI’s side, see:

github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

Generic sanity test on hardware ports

opened 02:32PM - 19 Jan 24 UTC
NiranSchneller

**Describe the bug** When deploying code that tries to initialize a PWM Port th…at is <= 0, the roboRIO doesn't do anything upon ENABLE, and when trying to redeploy code, it says build failed because of - discoverroborio. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1. Initialize a PWM Port which is <=0 2. Deploy code 3. Try to redeploy code, and see that the build fails on - discoverroborio. - Link to code: https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/blob/a2d45dbca406ee7bdc17d1da010c509006606dd2/hal/src/main/native/athena/PWM.cpp#L81 There are other files where the sanity check doesn't occur, I provided this specific one. **Expected behavior** The expected behavior is getting an error that the port we entered was invalid. **Desktop (please complete the following information):** - OS: Windows 11. - Project Information: Project Version: 2024.1.1 VS Code Version: 1.84.0 WPILib Extension Version: 2024.1.1 C++ Extension Version: 1.17.5 Java Extension Version: 1.23.0 Java Debug Extension Version: 0.52.0 Java Dependencies Extension Version 0.23.0 Java Version: 17 Java Location: C:\Users\Public\wpilib\2024\jdk Vendor Libraries: NavX (2024.1.0) CTRE-Phoenix (v5) (5.33.0) CTRE-Phoenix (v6) (24.1.0) REVLib (2024.2.0) WPILib-New-Commands (1.0.0) **Additional context** It started when we had problems deploying our robot code. The code deployment failed on discoverroborio, so e naturally though it was a networking issue of some sort. After endless pings, network checks and version switches (2023 and back), we realized they weren't the problem, and the problem had to be in the code itself. After many more hours of debugging, we found out the problem was that we had initialized a PWM Port of 0 in the code. While that fixed it, I still could not find find any correlation between the problem (Invalid port) and the error that we got, since we should have gotten an error about the port. So out of curiosity, I looked at the JNI files in this repository. After close inspection, I found out that there is no checking for PWM ports that are <= 0. Not checking this is what caused the RIO to crash everytime we tried to redeploy code, when the previous deployed code had that incorrect port.
